Wanting to save Ariel, Triton confronts Ursula. However, the deal that she made with Ariel is unbreakable. Ariel and Eric reunite on the surface just before a gigantic Ursula separates them. Just as Eric is about to be killed, Ariel commandeers a wrecked ship and impales Ursula with its splintered bowsprit. Once Ursula dies, Triton comes back to life; he and Ariel recognize the other's sacrifice for them.

In the early stages of the film's development, Lindsay Lohan expressed interest in playing the role of Ariel. Halle Bailey was the first to audition for the role after Rob Marshall saw her perform Donny Hathaway's 1972 single 'Where Is the Love' at the 61st Annual Grammy Awards. According to Marshall, hundreds of other girls also tried out for the part, but she 'set the bar so high that nobody surpassed it.'
Halle Bailey was cast as the lead role of Ariel in 'The Little Mermaid' remake.

Director Rob Marshall's conscious decision to cast a relatively unknown actress as Vanessa, since Melissa McCarthy was already playing Ursula, allowed Jessica Alexander to showcase her talent for transforming into the sea witch. Director Marshall praised her for being 'a beautiful and charismatic' actress who could convincingly play demonic roles. Alexander herself enjoyed portraying such a character.
According to reports, Kacey Musgraves was also considered for the role of Vanessa in the live-action adaptation of The Little Mermaid. However, Jessica Alexander ultimately landed the part.

Visual effects director Rob Marshall explained that creating the underwater environments for the 'Under the Sea' sequence involved a lot of work in advance with John DeLuca and himself creating these musical sequences to prep it in advance from storyboards to something called pre-visualization, which is almost like a little mini-animated film, so we know how it flowed and how it worked ... You are creating a world, you're creating creatures, but it's very important to me that it feels real – you have to believe, you have to care about them, you have to follow their journey.

Visual effects director Rob Marshall revealed that his work on Disney's Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides, which featured a mermaid character named Tamara, helped influence his work on The Little Mermaid, using similar live-action and CGI techniques to bring Ariel, her sisters and King Triton to life. He called it 'a great launching point for us' and showed his work on Pirates to the crew and visual effects team to break down the process.

The colorful tails of the merpeople characters, including Ariel's sisters, were designed by Marshall's frequent costume designer Colleen Atwood, who used real fish as references to make each of the tails look more distinct from one another.

In August 2023, special effects artist Christine Overs filed a lawsuit against the film's producers over an accident that occurred on the film set that resulted in a broken wrist. Sandcastle Pictures, the Disney-owned production company responsible for filming, has admitted responsibility for the accident but disputes the amount Overs is seeking.

node_2: intense being all over the place
edge: During the filming of 'For the First Time', the emotions and energy level were intense and chaotic, as described by the cast member who was speaking in the given context.

The speaker mentioned in the context expressed intense emotions, including crying, while filming 'For the First Time' due to being overwhelmed by the significance of the song and its connection to each cast member.
In the context, it was revealed that one of the new songs for the live-action adaptation of 'The Little Mermaid', 'For the First Time', will feature Ariel in her human form.
According to the context, actor Daveed Diggs might rap in the live-action adaptation of 'The Little Mermaid'.

In the context, Alan Menken revealed that a new song for the live-action adaptation of 'The Little Mermaid', titled 'The Scuttlebutt', will feature Sebastian and Scuttle trying to figure out why Prince Eric has decided to marry, believing it must be Ariel but actually it's Ursula in disguise.

Menken revealed that the first of the four new songs, 'Wild Unchartered Waters', was written during the film's development for Prince Eric. Marshall wanted a new song for this moment of waves and all the wildness of what's out there in the ocean because Ariel represented that to Prince Eric; she being the girl who saved his life. Live action films are really a director's medium.
The fourth song did not make the final cut, but was supposed to be a new song for King Triton entitled 'Impossible Child'. Menken and the filmmakers felt that it 'dramaturgically' was not needed.

Menken explained that some of the lyrics for 'Poor Unfortunate Souls' were updated because 'people have gotten very sensitive about the idea that Prince Eric would, in any way, force himself on Ariel.'

Menken also explained that some of the lyrics for 'Kiss the Girl' were updated because 'people have gotten very sensitive about the idea that Prince Eric would, in any way, force himself on Ariel.' However, this was only for lines that might make young girls somehow feel that they shouldn't speak out of turn, even though Ursula is clearly manipulating Ariel to give up her voice.

Two songs from the original film were cut: 'Daughters of Triton', sung by Ariel's sisters and 'Les Poissons', sung by the character of Eric's French cook Chef Louis. Menken explained the reasons for cutting the former, saying that it felt 'not needed' given the new approach the filmmakers gave to the sisters, and that they wanted the film to begin 'with a much more of a live-action feel of the ocean and meeting Ariel, and then we wait a little bit, make you wait until we get to 'Part of Your World.' And I think that was, you know, it was an amazing choice because it just builds the power and anticipation.'

Menken explained the reasons for cutting 'Les Poissons', sung by the character of Eric's French cook Chef Louis, who also was cut from the film. Marshall explained 'It's literally a Saturday morning cartoon section. If we had filmed it – I don't know how we would've filmed it – it never would have played. It's also a vacation from the story and has nothing to do with the story, so you can't do that in a live-action film.'

Halle Bailey delivers a standout performance as the titular mermaid in Disney's latest live-action adaptation, elevating the film and earning it a spot among the studio's most enjoyable reimaginings according to Rotten Tomatoes' consensus.
The film received mixed reviews from critics, with 67% of 346 critics' reviews on Rotten Tomatoes being positive and an average rating of 6.3/10 according to the same website.
According to Rotten Tomatoes, 67% of 346 critics' reviews are positive for Disney's latest live-action adaptation of The Little Mermaid.

node_2: less compelling than the animated original
edge: Ann Hornaday of The Washington Post compared the film to a mixed bag and noted that although it honors its source material with a grand scope, it never precisely proved that it ever needed to exist. She also implied that the live-action version falls short in comparison to the animated original.
Rachel LaBonte of Screen Rant mentioned that although the film is bolstered by deeper characterization and a grand scope, it grapples with flaws.
Helen O'Hara of Empire stated that although the live-action version is darker and less compelling than the animated original, it is saved by the story's own eternal magic.
Helen O'Hara of Empire also mentioned that although Bailey's performance is charming, the film is saved by her charisma and McCarthy's sass.
Moira MacDonald of The Seattle Times praised Bailey's singing voice, stating that it has both sweetness and power, and her smile is the sort on which dreams dance.

According to Angelica Jade Bastién, Disney betrays its own lack of imagination by presenting a carbon copy and superfluous added material in 'The Little Mermaid' adaptation that lacks the essential misreading of what made its original children's fare such a joy to audiences in the first place.

According to Johnny Oleksinski, 'The Little Mermaid' adaptation is less far better two-dimensional painted drawings and more lifeless than Disney's previous flesh-and-blood cash grab because of the use of CGI and brand new material that make it feel artificial.
According to Justin Chang, the differences in 'The Little Mermaid' adaptation seem motivated less by a spirit of imagination than one of joyless anxiety.
According to Kat Rosenfield, 'The Little Mermaid' adaptation places less trust in its intended audience of children than the original did, now that they are grown up.
According to Kat Rosenfield, 'The Little Mermaid' adaptation is infantilizing and propaganda because it pales in comparison to the original.
In this context, the term 'children' refers to offspring who have reached adulthood and are now considered 'grown up'. This highlights the concept of growth and maturation.

The author compares the original animated film to its live-action adaptation. They suggest that while the animation is successful, the live-action version fails to translate well due to the use of CGI and poor lighting, highlighting the importance of aesthetics in filmmaking.

The author notes that the pursuit of realism in these live-action adaptations detracts from the original magic of the animated films. They suggest that while there are certain aspects of reality that should be incorporated, such as proper lighting, too much emphasis on realism can lead to blandness and a loss of enchantment.

The author criticizes the length of these live-action adaptations, suggesting that they are too drawn out. This highlights the importance of appropriate pacing and storytelling techniques in filmmaking.
The author describes the CGI characters as either 'boring' or 'horrifying'. This highlights the challenge of creating photorealistic talking animals that are both visually stunning and believable.
The author notes that in making these films 'live action', changes have been made to aesthetics and story. This highlights the interconnectedness of various aspects of filmmaking.

The announcement of Halle Bailey as Ariel in the live-action adaptation sparked mixed reactions from the public due to the fact that Bailey is African-American, while the original character was Caucasian with red hair. Critics argued that a black mermaid did not adhere to the original story and that the adaptation should be as close to the original as possible.

The negative response to Bailey's casting after the release of the teaser trailer became viral and elicited the hashtag #NotMyAriel. Many criticized the casting, citing reasons such as Ariel being Caucasian with red hair in the original story and mermaids being pale, not black, as they are underwater creatures.
Lin-Manuel Miranda, the film's producer and lyricist, criticized the negative response to Bailey's casting and described it as being racist.
The criticism after the teaser trailer release became viral and sparked controversy, with many media outlets and people criticizing those who opposed Bailey's casting as being racist.
Some critics argued that the negative response was due to a perceived trend of whitewashing in Hollywood, as Ariel is one of the most well-known Disney princesses.
Others argued that the criticism was a result of a lack of representation for black actresses in Hollywood and the cultural significance of Ariel as a beloved Disney character.
Both actresses expressed excitement about each other's portrayal of Ariel during an interview in August 2019.
Benson praised Bailey's portrayal of Ariel, highlighting the importance of a character's spirit over physical appearance.
Norwood praised the casting of Bailey as Ariel, acknowledging her significance as the first woman of color to play Cinderella.
Rose praised the casting of Bailey as Ariel, recognizing her importance as the voice of Disney's first official African-American princess.
Zegler voiced her support for Bailey, acknowledging the significance of two Black women playing iconic Disney roles.
Bailey has been receiving criticisms from racist trolls on social media, but she is ignoring their comments and focusing on the anticipation for the film's release.
Bailey acknowledged the significance of her portrayal of Ariel to the Black community, highlighting its importance for them to see themselves in iconic Disney roles.

node_1: the little mermaid ii: return to the sea
edge: Bailey and Jonah Hauer-King spoke about the animated sequel The Little Mermaid II: Return to the Sea, saying that they liked it and they would agree to reprise their roles if it were adapted into live action.

Marshall hinted at the potential for sequels if the film is successful: "It's a classic story that has a lot of characters and a lot of interesting stories. I do think it's right for certain things. But you have to see how a movie plays, and how it does... I think there's always opportunity to find stories within stories. That's always a wonderful thing."
